FedAQ: Communication-Efficient Federated Edge Learning via Joint Uplink and Downlink Adaptive Quantization

Linping Qu,  Shenghui Song,  and Chi-Ying Tsui The work described in this paper was supported by a grant from the Research Grants Council of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region, China (Project Reference Number: AoE/E-601/22-R). Part of this work was presented at the IEEE Global Communications Conference (GLOBECOM), Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, Dec. 2022 [1]. Linping Qu, Shenghui Song, and Chi-Ying Tsui are with the Department of Electronic and Computer Engineering, Hong Kong University of Science and Technology, Hong Kong (e-mail: lqu@connect.ust.hk; eeshsong@ust.hk; eetsui@ust.hk).
Abstract

Federated learning (FL) is a powerful machine learning paradigm which leverages the data as well as the computational resources of clients, while protecting clients’ data privacy. However, the substantial model size and frequent aggregation between the server and clients result in significant communication overhead, making it challenging to deploy FL in resource-limited wireless networks. In this work, we aim to mitigate the communication overhead by using quantization. Previous research on quantization has primarily focused on the uplink communication, employing either fixed-bit quantization or adaptive quantization methods. In this work, we introduce a holistic approach by joint uplink and downlink adaptive quantization to reduce the communication overhead. In particular, we optimize the learning convergence by determining the optimal uplink and downlink quantization bit-length, with a communication energy constraint. Theoretical analysis shows that the optimal quantization levels depend on the range of model gradients or weights. Based on this insight, we propose a decreasing-trend quantization for the uplink and an increasing-trend quantization for the downlink, which aligns with the change of the model parameters during the training process. Experimental results show that, the proposed joint uplink and downlink adaptive quantization strategy can save up to 66.7% energy compared with the existing schemes.

Index Terms:
Federated learning (FL), quantization, communication-efficient, uplink and downlink

I Introduction

I-A Background

Federated learning (FL) [2, 3] is an emerging technique to tackle the data isolation problem by distributed learning technology. Instead of sharing the data of different clients, FL only shares model parameters such that the clients’ privacy can be protected[4]. However, FL faces a significant challenge in terms of communication overhead[5, 6, 7, 8], which arises from three aspects[9, 7]. Firstly, numerous communication rounds between the clients and the parameter server may be required to achieve a satisfactory performance. Secondly, each communication round involves a potentially large number of participating clients, which can range from thousands to millions. Lastly, the size of deep neural network (DNN) model keeps increasing, e.g., from megabytes to gigabyte size. Consequently, the clients need to transmit and receive a substantial amount of data to complete an FL task, resulting in high energy consumption and long latency. This poses a challenge for resource-limited wireless networks and clients, calling for a communication-efficient design.

I-B Related Works

Several methods have been proposed in the literature to tackle the communication overhead issue in FL. These methods can be categorized into three lines of research: infrequent communication, model sparsification, and quantization.

Infrequent Communication: One approach to reduce communication overhead is to accelerate training and reduce the number of communication rounds between clients and the server. Local SGD and FedAvg algorithms, as proposed in [10] and [11], perform multiple steps of local updating before model aggregation, reducing the number of communication rounds at the expense of local computation. The authors of [5] and [12] considered the communication design for the scenario of non-identically independent distribution (I.I.D). The number of communication round is further reduced by one-shot training [13]. Theoretical analyses of periodic averaging were given in [14, 15, 16, 17, 18], while [6] and [19] analyzed the impact of communication frequency on convergence rate and proposed to adaptively modify the frequency during training, aiming to save communication overhead and keep a low error floor. Additionally, [20] and [7] combined infrequent communication with other strategies such as model sparsification and quantization to further save communication.

Model sparsification: Model sparsification techniques aim to reduce the number of DNN model parameters. These techniques involve selecting the most significant gradients based on a predefined percentage or threshold[21, 22, 23, 24, 25]. Other techniques like low rank[7, 26] and the lottery ticket hypothesis[27] were adopted in FL to reduce the dimensions of gradients. Aggressive reduction on parameters can be achieved by these methods, but they often require empirical knowledge and manual efforts. Flexible gradient compression techniques have also been proposed where the sparsity rate is determined automatically[28, 29]. Metrics based on gradient variance [30], standard deviation [31], or entropy [32] were heuristically used to determine the sparsity. Theoretical convergence analyses for model sparsification have also been studied in [33, 34, 35].

Quantization: Quantization is a lossy compression method that is orthogonal to infrequent communication and model sparsification. It aims to reduce the bit length of transmitted parameters [36, 37]. Shorter bit-length quantization can significantly reduce communication overhead at the cost of communication errors that affect learning accuracy. Finding a suitable bit-length with a good trade-off between the communication overhead and learning accuracy is crucial in quantized FL [38, 8].

The authors of [37] proposed a fixed 8-bit quantization on gradients. [39] and [40] used ternary values (+1, 0, -1) to represent all the gradients while [41, 42, 43] proposed 1-bit quantization. Besides the pursuit of shorter bit-length, other approaches used different types of quantizers to replace the classical stochastic uniform quantizer. Vector quantization [44, 45, 46] and clustering-based quantization [47] were proposed to better fit the characteristics of FL. To mitigate quantization errors, methods like random rotation [7], [48], error feedback [49], [50], and lazily aggregated gradients [51] have been proposed. Theoretical analyses of convergence rate for quantized FL were investigated in [20],[52] and [53]. However, the optimum bit-length may vary for different models and tasks, and thus requires significant manual effort to determine the best bit-length. Additionally, fixed-bit quantization may not adapt well to the dynamic training process. To address these issues, adaptive quantization has gained much attention.

Existing adaptive quantization schemes in FL mainly focused on the uplink communication and used an increasing-trend quantization approach, where a small bit length is used in the early training stages, while a longer bit length is employed in the late training stages [38, 8, 54, 55]. Criteria for changing the bit-length have been proposed. For example, [38] used the root mean square (RMS) value of gradients to evaluate the impact of quantization on training loss. If the RMS value is large, a large number of quantization bit will be assigned, and vice versa. Reinforcement learning was proposed in [8] to determine the quantization bit based on training loss. Other approaches, such as [55] and [54], utilized training loss or the mean to standard deviation ratio (MSDR) of gradients as the criteria for selecting the quantization bits. However, they mainly focused on the uplink transmission without theoretical support. Downlink quantization also holds significance for energy-sensitive clients. Reducing the bit length of model parameters in the downlink not only saves receiving energy but also decreases channel decoding energy.

I-C Contributions and Organization

In this work, we propose a novel approach to decrease energy consumption and communication latency by joint uplink and downlink adaptive quantization.

To determine the dynamic quantization bit-length in both the uplink and downlink, we formulate an optimization problem. For a given energy constraint, we optimize the learning convergence by allocating the bit-length in the uplink and downlink during various training stages. The solution of the optimization problem reveals that the optimal quantization bit exhibits a positive correlation with the range of the model weights or gradients.

The main contributions of this work are outlined as follows:

  • •

    Joint Uplink and Downlink Quantization: Unlike existing studies that solely focus on a single link, this work emphasizes the joint consideration of both the uplink and downlink to achieve more substantial reduction in energy consumption.

  • •

    Rigorous Theoretical Analysis: The design of our approach is rooted in rigorous theoretical analysis, distinguishing it from intuitive or heuristic approach. The numerical range of model updates and model weights are found to be critical in making quantization decisions.

  • •

    Based on the theoretical analyses and the characteristics of FL, decreasing-trend quantization in the uplink and increasing-trend quantization in the downlink is motivated, whose superiority is demonstrated by extensive experiments.

The remainder of the paper is organized as follows. In Section II, the system model is described. In Section III, comprehensive theoretical analysis of joint uplink and downlink quantized FL is provided. The formulation of the optimization problem is discussed and the algorithm based on the theoretical analysis is then described. In Section IV, the theoretical analysis and the corresponding optimization solutions for two special cases: uplink-only quantization and downlink-only quantization, are given. In Section V, experimental results are povided and discussed. Finally, the conclusion is drawn in Section VI.

Notations. The notations used in this article are listed in Table I.

II System Model

In this section, we will introduce the concerned FL system with joint uplink and downlink quantization.

II-A Federated Learning

The goal of FL is to train a global model by utilizing the data residing on different clients. The problem can be formulated as

m​i​n𝐰∈ℝd​f​(𝐰)=∑i=1npi​fi​(𝐰),𝐰superscriptℝ𝑑𝑚𝑖𝑛𝑓𝐰subscriptsuperscript𝑛𝑖1subscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝑓𝑖𝐰\displaystyle{\underset{\mathbf{w}\in{\mathbb{R}^{d}}}{min}\ f(\mathbf{w})=\sum\limits^{n}_{i=1}p_{i}f_{i}(\mathbf{w})}, (1)

where n𝑛n denotes the number of clients, pisubscript𝑝𝑖p_{i} is the ratio between the data size of the it​hsuperscript𝑖𝑡ℎi^{th} client to that of all clients, and fi​(𝐰)subscript𝑓𝑖𝐰f_{i}(\mathbf{w}) represents the training loss of the it​hsuperscript𝑖𝑡ℎi^{th} client on its local datasets. In the mt​hsuperscript𝑚𝑡ℎm^{th} round of communication, the server broadcasts the global model 𝐰msubscript𝐰𝑚\mathbf{w}_{m} to all the selected clients. After receiving the global model, each client performs τ𝜏\tau steps of local training by stochastic gradient descent (SGD) algorithm with a learning rate of η𝜂\eta. The local updating rule is given by

where t=0,…,τ−1𝑡0…𝜏1t=0,...,\tau-1, ∇~​fi​(𝐰m,ti)~∇subscript𝑓𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝐰𝑖𝑚𝑡\tilde{\nabla}f_{i}(\mathbf{w}^{i}_{m,t}) denotes the stochastic gradient computed from local datasets, and 𝐰m,0i=𝐰msubscriptsuperscript𝐰𝑖𝑚0subscript𝐰𝑚\mathbf{w}^{i}_{m,0}=\mathbf{w}_{m}.

After τ𝜏\tau steps of local training, the it​hsuperscript𝑖𝑡ℎi^{th} client obtains a new model 𝐰m,τisubscriptsuperscript𝐰𝑖𝑚𝜏\mathbf{w}^{i}_{m,\tau}, and the local model update is given by

Δ​𝐰mi=𝐰m,τi−𝐰m.Δsubscriptsuperscript𝐰𝑖𝑚subscriptsuperscript𝐰𝑖𝑚𝜏subscript𝐰𝑚\displaystyle\Delta\mathbf{w}^{i}_{m}=\mathbf{w}^{i}_{m,\tau}-\mathbf{w}_{m}. (3)

Then, each client uploads the local model update to the server, and the server will update the global model by

𝐰m+1=𝐰m+∑i=1npi​Δ​𝐰mi.subscript𝐰𝑚1subscript𝐰𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑝𝑖Δsubscriptsuperscript𝐰𝑖𝑚\displaystyle\mathbf{w}_{m+1}=\mathbf{w}_{m}+\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}\Delta\mathbf{w}^{i}_{m}. (4)

The new global model will be broadcast to selected clients for next round of communication.

II-B Quantization Model

In practice, both the model update Δ​𝐰miΔsubscriptsuperscript𝐰𝑖𝑚\Delta\mathbf{w}^{i}_{m} and global model 𝐰msubscript𝐰𝑚\mathbf{w}_{m} will be quantized during the uplink and downlink communication. In this paper, we adopt a widely utilized stochastic uniform quantizer[7][48]. In particular, for a given model 𝐰i∈ℝdsubscript𝐰𝑖superscriptℝ𝑑\mathbf{w}_{i}\in{\mathbb{R}^{d}}, we first compute its range, i.e., 𝐰im​a​x−𝐰im​i​nsuperscriptsubscript𝐰𝑖𝑚𝑎𝑥superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑖𝑚𝑖𝑛\mathbf{w}_{i}^{max}-\mathbf{w}_{i}^{min}, where 𝐰im​a​x=m​a​x1≤j≤d​𝐰i​(j)superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑖𝑚𝑎𝑥𝑚𝑎subscript𝑥1𝑗𝑑subscript𝐰𝑖𝑗\mathbf{w}_{i}^{max}=max_{1\leq j\leq d}\mathbf{w}_{i}(j) and 𝐰im​i​n=m​i​n1≤j≤d​𝐰i​(j)superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑖𝑚𝑖𝑛𝑚𝑖subscript𝑛1𝑗𝑑subscript𝐰𝑖𝑗\mathbf{w}_{i}^{min}=min_{1\leq j\leq d}\mathbf{w}_{i}(j) denote the maximum and minimum value of the model elements, respectively. With N𝑁N bit quantization, the range is divided into 2N−1superscript2𝑁12^{N}-1 bins. As shown in Figure 1, if 𝐰i​(j)subscript𝐰𝑖𝑗\mathbf{w}_{i}(j) is located in one bin whose lower bound and upper bound are h′superscriptℎ′h^{\prime} and h′′superscriptℎ′′h^{\prime\prime}, respectively, then the quantized value will be calculated as

Q​(𝐰i​(j))={h′,with probability ​h′′−𝐰i​(j)h′′−h′,h′′,otherwise.𝑄subscript𝐰𝑖𝑗casessuperscriptℎ′with probability superscriptℎ′′subscript𝐰𝑖𝑗superscriptℎ′′superscriptℎ′superscriptℎ′′otherwise\displaystyle Q(\mathbf{w}_{i}(j))=\begin{cases}h^{\prime},&\mbox{with probability }\frac{h^{\prime\prime}-\mathbf{w}_{i}(j)}{h^{\prime\prime}-h^{\prime}},\\ h^{\prime\prime},&\mbox{otherwise}.\end{cases} (5)

Let Q1​(⋅)subscript𝑄1⋅Q_{1}(\cdot) and Q2​(⋅)subscript𝑄2⋅Q_{2}(\cdot) denote the quantization function in the uplink and downlink communication, respectively. 𝐰m+1=𝐰m+∑i=1npi​Q1​(Δ​𝐰mi).subscript𝐰𝑚1subscript𝐰𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝑄1Δsubscriptsuperscript𝐰𝑖𝑚\displaystyle\mathbf{w}_{m+1}=\mathbf{w}_{m}+\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}Q_{1}(\Delta\mathbf{w}^{i}_{m}). (8)

III Theoretical Analysis and Design

In this section we will jointly design the uplink and downlink quantization to save the overall communication overhead. For that purpose, we first derive the convergence bound for FL with quantization error in the uplink and downlink. Then, we formulate the adaptive quantization issue into an optimization problem, whose objective is to minimize the learning convergence bound by tuning the quantization level in the uplink and downlink under an energy consumption constraint. Finally we solve the optimization problem theoretically and propose an algorithm based on the theoretical conclusion.

III-A Convergence Analysis

In this subsection, we derive the FL convergence bound with quantization. For that purpose, we first introduce three commonly-used assumptions.
Assumption 1 (Unbiased random quantizer) The quantization operation Q(⋅⋅\cdot) is unbiased and its variance is bounded by the quantization level and range of the parameters[48, 55]:

𝔼​[Q​(𝐰)|𝐰]=𝐰𝔼delimited-[]conditional𝑄𝐰𝐰𝐰\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[Q(\mathbf{w})|\mathbf{w}]=\mathbf{w}
𝔼​[‖Q​(𝐰)−𝐰‖2|𝐰]≤qs​R2​(𝐰),𝔼delimited-[]conditionalsuperscriptnorm𝑄𝐰𝐰2𝐰subscript𝑞𝑠superscript𝑅2𝐰\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[||Q(\mathbf{w})-\mathbf{w}||^{2}|\mathbf{w}]\leq q_{s}R^{2}(\mathbf{w}),

where R​(𝐰)=𝐰m​a​x−𝐰m​i​n𝑅𝐰subscript𝐰𝑚𝑎𝑥subscript𝐰𝑚𝑖𝑛R(\mathbf{w})=\mathbf{w}_{max}-\mathbf{w}_{min}, qs=ds2subscript𝑞𝑠𝑑superscript𝑠2q_{s}=\frac{d}{s^{2}}, and s𝑠s denotes the total number of quantization bins.
Assumption 2 (L-smoothness) The loss function f𝑓f is L-smooth with respect to 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w}. For any 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w}, 𝐰^∈ℝd^𝐰superscriptℝ𝑑\hat{\mathbf{w}}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, we have [55, 20]

The first and second terms on the right-hand side (RHS) of Eq.(9) capture the impact of uplink and downlink quantization, respectively. The third term captures the difference between the initial and final training loss. The fourth term comes from the stochastic gradient descending.

III-B Joint Uplink and Downlink Adaptive Quantization

Our target is to minimize the right-hand side of (9) under the total uplink and downlink energy constraint E𝐸E, by optimizing both the uplink quantization level smisuperscriptsubscript𝑠𝑚𝑖s_{m}^{i} and the downlink quantization level smsubscript𝑠𝑚s_{m}. (25)

Finally, to achieve the best learning performance, for a given K𝐾K rounds of communication with the energy budget of E𝐸E, the optimal quantization level for the uplink and downlink in the mt​hsuperscript𝑚𝑡ℎm^{th} communication round is

{u​p​l​i​n​k:b​i​tmi=⌈l​o​g2​(Rmi​(Δ​𝐰)α)⌉,d​o​w​n​l​i​n​k:b​i​tm=⌈l​o​g2​(Rm​(𝐰)β)⌉=⌈l​o​g2​(2​n​Rm​(𝐰)α)⌉.cases:𝑢𝑝𝑙𝑖𝑛𝑘𝑏𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑚𝑖𝑙𝑜subscript𝑔2superscriptsubscript𝑅𝑚𝑖Δ𝐰𝛼otherwise:𝑑𝑜𝑤𝑛𝑙𝑖𝑛𝑘𝑏𝑖subscript𝑡𝑚𝑙𝑜subscript𝑔2subscript𝑅𝑚𝐰𝛽𝑙𝑜subscript𝑔22𝑛subscript𝑅𝑚𝐰𝛼otherwise\displaystyle\begin{cases}uplink:\ bit_{m}^{i}=\lceil log_{2}(\frac{R_{m}^{i}(\Delta\mathbf{w})}{\alpha})\rceil,\\ downlink:\ bit_{m}=\lceil log_{2}(\frac{R_{m}(\mathbf{w})}{\beta})\rceil=\lceil log_{2}(\frac{\sqrt{2n}\ R_{m}(\mathbf{w})}{\alpha})\rceil.\end{cases} (26)

This shows that the optimal quantization bit depends on the range of communicated parameters. For the uplink, the optimal quantization bit depends on the range of the local model updates which has a decreasing trend, as shown in Fig. 2(a). For the downlink, the optimal quantization bit depends on the range of the global model which has an increasing trend, as shown in Fig. 2(b). This supports our quantization scheme using descending quantization in the uplink and ascending quantization in the downlink.

III-C Algorithm

Based on the theoretical analysis, we propose a joint uplink and downlink adaptive quantization scheme. The detailed bit-changing rule has been given in (26). The algorithm is summerized in Algorithm 1. Notice that in the mt​hsuperscript𝑚𝑡ℎm^{th} communication round, the global model weights are quantized before broadcasting, where the bit-length can be decided by the function of b​i​tm𝑏𝑖subscript𝑡𝑚bit_{m} in (26). Before uplink transmission, for the it​hsuperscript𝑖𝑡ℎi^{th} client, the model updates are quantized by following the function of b​i​tmi𝑏𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑚𝑖bit_{m}^{i} in (26).

IV Special Cases Analysis

In this section, we analyze the performance of two special cases: uplink-only quantization and downlink-only quantization.

IV-A Uplink-only Quantization

For uplink-only quantization, the downlink communication is assumed to be perfect. The problem can be formulated as, how to optimize the learning performance by tuning the uplink quantization level, for a given constraint on the uplink transmission energy. Because of page limitation, we here omit the detailed derivation process which is easy to obtain by making certain changes in our full-link theoretical analysis. After the derivation process, we get the following Theorem 2 for uplink-only quantization.
Theorem 2. For a given K communication rounds, the convergence bound is

which exactly matches the derivation result in our previous conference paper [1]. To minimize the convergence upper bound for a given uplink energy constraint, we formulate this problem into

α=21K​n​∑m=0K−1∑i∈[n]l​o​g2​Rmi​(Δ​𝐰)−E1K​n​d​e1𝛼superscript21𝐾𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑚0𝐾1subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛𝑙𝑜subscript𝑔2subscriptsuperscript𝑅𝑖𝑚Δ𝐰subscript𝐸1𝐾𝑛𝑑subscript𝑒1\displaystyle\alpha=2^{\frac{1}{Kn}\sum_{m=0}^{K-1}\sum_{i\in[n]}log_{2}R^{i}_{m}(\Delta\mathbf{w})-\frac{E_{1}}{Knde_{1}}} (29)

Since the range of local model updates has a decreasing trend, as shown in Fig.2(a), the optimized adaptive quantization bit in the uplink is expected to follow a descending trend. This conclusion is consistent with the results in our conference paper[1].

IV-B Downlink-only Quantization

For downlink-only quantization, the uplink communication is assumed to be perfect. The problem can be formulated as, how to optimize the learning performance by tuning the downlink quantization level, for a given constraint on the downlink receiving energy. After derivation, we get the following Theorem 3 for downlink-only quantization.
Theorem 3. For a given K communication rounds, the convergence bound is

To minimize the convergence upper bound for a given downlink energy constraint, we formulate this problem into

Since the range of the global model has an increasing trend, as shown in Fig.2(b), the optimized adaptive quantization bit in the downlink is expected to follow an increasing trend.

V Experiment

In this section, we perform experiments on open datasets to validate the effectiveness of the proposed adaptive quantization method. The experiments will be performed in three scenarios: joint uplink and downlink quantization, uplink-only quantization, and downlink-only quantization.

V-A Datasets and DNN Models

Three datasets are used in the experiments: MNIST[56], Fashion-MNIST[57], and CIFAR-10[58]. The training datasets of MNIST, Fashion-MNIST, and CIFAR-10 are split among all clients in an I.I.D manner, and the test datasets are used to perform validation on the server side.

The experiments utilize four DNN networks:

  • •

    LeNet-300-100[59]: This is a fully connected neural network with two hidden layers, with 300 and 100 neurons for each, and a final softmax output layer with around 0.27M parameters in total.

  • •

    Vanilla CNN [10]: This network consists of two 5×\times5 convolution layers (the first has 32 filters and the second has 64 filters, each followed by 2×\times2 max pooling and ReLu activation), one fully connected layer with 512 unities followed by ReLu activation, and a final softmax output layer with around 0.58M parameters in total.

  • •

    7-layer CNN: This network consists of four 3×\times3 convolutional layers with padding 1 (the first with 48 filters followed by ReLu activation, the second with 96 filters followed by ReLu activation, 2×\times2 max pooling, and 0.25 dropout, the third with 192 filters followed by ReLu activation, and the fourth with 256 filters followed by ReLu activation, 2×\times2 max pooling, and 0.25 dropout), two fully connected layers (the first with 512 unities followed by ReLu activation, the second with 64 unities followed by ReLu activation and 0.25 dropout), and a final softmax output layer with around 9.07M parameters in total.

  • •

    ResNet-18[60]: ResNet is a very famous neural network for image recognition tasks. The detailed network structure can be found at https://pytorch.org/hub/pytorch_vision_resnet. In this work, we choose ResNet-18, which contains around 11.6M parameters in total.

We conduct four sets of experiments: LeNet-300-100 on MNIST, vanilla CNN on Fashion-MNIST, 7-layer CNN on CIFAR-10, and ResNet-18 on CIFAR-10. All experiments are conducted on a computer with a 6th Gen Intel(R) Xeon(R) W-2245 @3.90GHz CPU and NVIDIA GeForce RTX 3090 GPU.

Hyper-parameters: In this work, we suggest to set α𝛼\alpha between 0.003–0.005. The transmitting and receiving energy units are assumed to be e1=e2=1​p​J/bsubscript𝑒1subscript𝑒21𝑝𝐽𝑏e_{1}=e_{2}=1pJ/b. For the local training, the batch size is set to 64, and the momentum is 0.5 in the SGD optimizer. We set the learning rate at 0.01 and local update steps at 5. Ten local clients are used in the LeNet-300-100 on MNIST, vanilla CNN on Fashion-MNIST, and 7-layer CNN on CIFAR-10 experiments. Because the model size of ResNet-18 is much larger than the above three models, considering about the simulation time, four local clients are used in the ResNet-18 on CIFAR-10 experiment. We compare both the training loss and test accuracy for all the experiments. In this paper, the training loss is calculated as the average loss of all clients’ local training [61].

V-B Joint Uplink and Downlink Adaptive Quantization

To the best of our knowledge, most existing quantization works focus on only one-side communication and there is no joint uplink and downlink adaptive quantization work. So we compare the joint uplink and downlink adaptive quantization with the best fixed-bit quantization scheme. For the fixed quantization, we tried 2-bit, 4-bit, 8-bit, and 16-bit quantization, and 8-bit quantization is found to be the best quantization scheme. Thus, our adaptive quantization is compared with fixed 8-bit quantization.

The results of the four experiments are shown in Fig. 3, where (a)–(c) are the results of LeNet-300-100 on MNIST, (d)–(f) are the results of vanilla CNN on Fashion-MNIST, (g)–(i) are the results of 7-layer CNN on CIFAR-10, and (j)-(l) are the results of ResNet-18 on CIFAR-10. First, let us look at the energy efficiency. It can be observed from (a),(d),(g), and (j) that the proposed adaptive quantization method consumes less energy than the optimal fixed quantization, i.e., 8-bit quantization. For example, as shown in (d), to achieve the same test accuracy of 91.3% on the Fashion-MNIST dataset, the fixed 8-bit quantization scheme consumes 5.86mJ, while our scheme only consumes 2.80mJ, which achieves a reduction of 52.2% of the communication energy. The detailed comparison can be found in Table II. Regarding convergence speed, Fig.3 (b),(e),(h), and (k) show that achieving the same test accuracy or training loss, the proposed adaptive scheme consumes a similar number of communication rounds with the fixed 8-bit quantization. Thus, to achieve the same learning performance, our method can save energy consumption without sacrificing convergence rate. This superior performance results from the effective strategy for bit resource allocation. Furthermore, as shown in (c),(f),(i), and (l), the quantization level shows a decreasing trend in the uplink, and an increasing trend in the downlink, which is consistent with the theoretical analyses.

V-C Uplink Only Design

In this sub-section, we conduct experiments with adaptive quantization only in the uplink, and no quantization in the downlink. Many works have focused on uplink quantization, and we compare the proposed scheme with the state-of-the-art AdaQuantFL, which uses increasing-trend quantization[55].

Fig.4 provides detailed results of the energy efficiency, convergence rate, range of parameters, and bit-changing curves in the experiments. In Fig. 4, (a)–(d) in the first row are the results for LeNet-300-100 on MNIST, (e)–(h) in the second row are the results for vanilla CNN on Fashion-MNIST, (i)–(l) in the third row are the results for 7-layer CNN on CIFAR-10, and (m)–(p) in the last row are the results for ResNet-18 on CIFAR-10. The results for energy efficiency, in Fig.4, (a),(e),(i), and (m) show that the descending quantization can achieve the same test accuracy or training loss as AdQuantFL but with lower energy consumption. Take the experiment of the vanilla CNN on Fashion-MNIST as an example. To achieve the test accuracy of 91.0%, AdaQuantFL consumes 2.0mJ of transmitting energy, while the proposed scheme only consumes 0.71mJ, indicating an energy saving ratio of 64.5%. In Fig.4, (b),(f),(j), and (n) demonstrate that the proposed scheme can converge faster to the same test accuracy than AdaQuantFL. The main reason is that a longer bit-length at the early training stage can help to enhance the convergence speed. More detailed explanation is provided in [1]. Fig.4 (c),(g),(k), and (o) show that the range of local model updates always shows a decreasing trend because the model stabilizes as training goes on and the model updates become smaller and smaller. Finally, the quantization level curves in subfigures (d), (h), (l), and (p) show an increasing trend for AdaQuantFL and a decreasing trend for the proposed scheme. This agrees with the theoretical analysis. A detailed comparison of the four experiments can be found in Table III.

V-D Downlink Only Design

In this section, we conduct experiments with adaptive quantization only in the downlink, and no quantization in the uplink. Few prior works have focused on downlink quantization. We compare the proposed increasing-trend quantization with the optimum fixed-bit quantization, i.e., 8-bit quantization, in the downlink.

Fig.5 presents the results for LeNet-300-100 on MNIST, vanilla CNN on Fashion-MNIST, 7-layer CNN on CIFAR-10, and ResNet-18 on CIFAR-10 row by row. The first column of Fig.5 shows that, for all experiments, the proposed quantization scheme can always achieve the same test accuracy or same training loss at lower downlink energy consumption compared with the optimum fixed-bit quantization scheme. Taking the vanilla CNN on Fashion-MNIST experiment as an example, to achieve the test accuracy of 91.0%, the 8-bit quantization consumes 2.10mJ while the proposed scheme only consumes 1.73mJ, indicating an energy saving ratio of 17.6%. As shown in the second column, the proposed method has a similar convergence speed to the fixed 8-bit quantization. So the proposed method saves downlink energy without any sacrifice of learning performance. The third column of Fig.5 shows that different from the range of local model updates, the range of the global model weights shows an increasing trend. This is because as training goes on, the wider range of model parameters provides a better generalization capacity to capture different training data. The quantization level in the downlink is also designed based on the range of the global model, so it shows an increasing trend with training as shown in the last column of Fig. 5. The detailed comparison of the four experiments can be found in Table IV.

VI Conclusion

In this paper, we proposed a joint uplink and downlink adaptive quantization scheme to save the communication overhead for FL systems. For that purpose, we first derived the convergence bound of FL with both uplink and downlink quantization errors. Then, we formulated an optimization problem that is to achieve the best learning performance under energy constraints by tuning uplink and downlink quantization levels. The results showed that the optimal quantization level depends on the range of communicated parameters. Additionally, it is observed that the range of local model updates in the uplink has a decreasing trend, while the range of the global model weights has an increasing trend. Accordingly, we propose to adopt decreasing-trend quantization in the uplink and increasing-trend quantization in the downlink. Comprehensive experiments in three scenarios: joint uplink and downlink quantization, uplink-only quantization, and downlink-only quantization showed that the proposed method can save significant amount of communication energy, while maintaining the same or even better learning performance than the existing schemes.

VI-B Proof of Lemma 2

According to [20] Section 8.3, for perfect downlink transmission, we have

𝔼​f​(𝐰¯m,τ)𝔼𝑓subscript¯𝐰𝑚𝜏\displaystyle\mathbb{E}f(\bar{\mathbf{w}}_{m,\tau}) ≤𝔼​f​(𝐰m)−η2​∑t=0τ−1𝔼​‖∇f​(𝐰¯m,t)‖2absent𝔼𝑓subscript𝐰𝑚𝜂2superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝜏1𝔼superscriptnorm∇𝑓subscript¯𝐰𝑚𝑡2\displaystyle\leq\mathbb{E}f(\mathbf{w}_{m})-\frac{\eta}{2}\sum_{t=0}^{\tau-1}\mathbb{E}\|\nabla f(\bar{\mathbf{w}}_{m,t})\|^{2}
−η​(12​n−L​η2​n−L2​η2​τ​(τ−1)n)​∑t=0τ−1∑i∈[n]𝔼​‖∇f​(𝐰m,ti)‖2𝜂12𝑛𝐿𝜂2𝑛superscript𝐿2superscript𝜂2𝜏𝜏1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝜏1subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛𝔼superscriptnorm∇𝑓superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑚𝑡𝑖2\displaystyle-\eta(\frac{1}{2n}-\frac{L\eta}{2n}-\frac{L^{2}\eta^{2}\tau(\tau-1)}{n})\sum_{t=0}^{\tau-1}\sum_{i\in[n]}\mathbb{E}\|\nabla f(\mathbf{w}_{m,t}^{i})\|^{2}
+L​τ​η2​σ22​n+L2​η3​σ2​(n+1)​τ​(τ−1)2​n.𝐿𝜏superscript𝜂2superscript𝜎22𝑛superscript𝐿2superscript𝜂3superscript𝜎2𝑛1𝜏𝜏12𝑛\displaystyle+\frac{L\tau\eta^{2}\sigma^{2}}{2n}+\frac{L^{2}\eta^{3}\sigma^{2}(n+1)\tau(\tau-1)}{2n}. (52)

When the downlink model is quantized, (52) will become

𝔼​f​(𝐰¯m,τ)𝔼𝑓subscript¯𝐰𝑚𝜏\displaystyle\mathbb{E}f(\bar{\mathbf{w}}_{m,\tau}) ≤𝔼​f​(Q2​(𝐰m))−η2​∑t=0τ−1𝔼​‖∇f​(𝐰¯m,t)‖2absent𝔼𝑓subscript𝑄2subscript𝐰𝑚𝜂2superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝜏1𝔼superscriptnorm∇𝑓subscript¯𝐰𝑚𝑡2\displaystyle\leq\mathbb{E}f(Q_{2}(\mathbf{w}_{m}))-\frac{\eta}{2}\sum_{t=0}^{\tau-1}\mathbb{E}\|\nabla f(\bar{\mathbf{w}}_{m,t})\|^{2}
−η​(12​n−L​η2​n−L2​η2​τ​(τ−1)n)​∑t=0τ−1∑i∈[n]𝔼​‖∇f​(𝐰m,ti)‖2𝜂12𝑛𝐿𝜂2𝑛superscript𝐿2superscript𝜂2𝜏𝜏1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝜏1subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛𝔼superscriptnorm∇𝑓superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑚𝑡𝑖2\displaystyle-\eta(\frac{1}{2n}-\frac{L\eta}{2n}-\frac{L^{2}\eta^{2}\tau(\tau-1)}{n})\sum_{t=0}^{\tau-1}\sum_{i\in[n]}\mathbb{E}\|\nabla f(\mathbf{w}_{m,t}^{i})\|^{2}
+L​τ​η2​σ22​n+L2​η3​σ2​(n+1)​τ​(τ−1)2​n.𝐿𝜏superscript𝜂2superscript𝜎22𝑛superscript𝐿2superscript𝜂3superscript𝜎2𝑛1𝜏𝜏12𝑛\displaystyle+\frac{L\tau\eta^{2}\sigma^{2}}{2n}+\frac{L^{2}\eta^{3}\sigma^{2}(n+1)\tau(\tau-1)}{2n}. (53)

Since loss function f𝑓f is L𝐿L-smooth, we have

f​(Q2​(𝐰m))𝑓subscript𝑄2subscript𝐰𝑚\displaystyle f(Q_{2}(\mathbf{w}_{m})) =f​(𝐰m+Q2​(𝐰m)−𝐰m)absent𝑓subscript𝐰𝑚subscript𝑄2subscript𝐰𝑚subscript𝐰𝑚\displaystyle=f(\mathbf{w}_{m}+Q_{2}(\mathbf{w}_{m})-\mathbf{w}_{m})
≤f​(𝐰m)+⟨∇f​(𝐰m),Q2​(𝐰m)−𝐰m⟩+L2​‖Q2​(𝐰m)−𝐰m‖2.absent𝑓subscript𝐰𝑚∇𝑓subscript𝐰𝑚subscript𝑄2subscript𝐰𝑚subscript𝐰𝑚𝐿2superscriptnormsubscript𝑄2subscript𝐰𝑚subscript𝐰𝑚2\displaystyle\leq f(\mathbf{w}_{m})+\left\langle\nabla f(\mathbf{w}_{m}),Q_{2}(\mathbf{w}_{m})-\mathbf{w}_{m}\right\rangle+\frac{L}{2}||Q_{2}(\mathbf{w}_{m})-\mathbf{w}_{m}||^{2}. (54)

Then we take the expectation of both sides of (54). Since Q2​(𝐰m)subscript𝑄2subscript𝐰𝑚Q_{2}(\mathbf{w}_{m}) is unbiased on 𝐰msubscript𝐰𝑚\mathbf{w}_{m} (according to Assumption 1), i.e., 𝔼​Q2​(𝐰m)=𝔼​𝐰m𝔼subscript𝑄2subscript𝐰𝑚𝔼subscript𝐰𝑚\mathbb{E}Q_{2}(\mathbf{w}_{m})=\mathbb{E}\mathbf{w}_{m}, we have

𝔼​f​(Q2​(𝐰m))≤𝔼​f​(𝐰m)+L2​𝔼​‖Q2​(𝐰m)−𝐰m‖2≤𝔼​f​(𝐰m)+L​d⋅Rm2​(𝐰m)2​sm2.𝔼𝑓subscript𝑄2subscript𝐰𝑚𝔼𝑓subscript𝐰𝑚𝐿2𝔼superscriptnormsubscript𝑄2subscript𝐰𝑚subscript𝐰𝑚2𝔼𝑓subscript𝐰𝑚⋅𝐿𝑑subscriptsuperscript𝑅2𝑚subscript𝐰𝑚2superscriptsubscript𝑠𝑚2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}f(Q_{2}(\mathbf{w}_{m}))\leq\mathbb{E}f(\mathbf{w}_{m})+\frac{L}{2}\mathbb{E}||Q_{2}(\mathbf{w}_{m})-\mathbf{w}_{m}||^{2}\leq\mathbb{E}f(\mathbf{w}_{m})+\frac{Ld\cdot R^{2}_{m}(\mathbf{w}_{m})}{2s_{m}^{2}}. (55)

Combining (53) and (55), we get

𝔼​f​(𝐰¯m,τ)𝔼𝑓subscript¯𝐰𝑚𝜏\displaystyle\mathbb{E}f(\bar{\mathbf{w}}_{m,\tau}) ≤𝔼​f​(𝐰m)+L​d⋅Rm2​(𝐰m)2​sm2−η2​∑t=0τ−1𝔼​‖∇f​(𝐰¯m,t)‖2absent𝔼𝑓subscript𝐰𝑚⋅𝐿𝑑subscriptsuperscript𝑅2𝑚subscript𝐰𝑚2superscriptsubscript𝑠𝑚2𝜂2superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝜏1𝔼superscriptnorm∇𝑓subscript¯𝐰𝑚𝑡2\displaystyle\leq\mathbb{E}f(\mathbf{w}_{m})+\frac{Ld\cdot R^{2}_{m}(\mathbf{w}_{m})}{2s_{m}^{2}}-\frac{\eta}{2}\sum_{t=0}^{\tau-1}\mathbb{E}\|\nabla f(\bar{\mathbf{w}}_{m,t})\|^{2}
−η​(12​n−L​η2​n−L2​η2​τ​(τ−1)n)​∑t=0τ−1∑i∈[n]𝔼​‖∇f​(𝐰m,ti)‖2𝜂12𝑛𝐿𝜂2𝑛superscript𝐿2superscript𝜂2𝜏𝜏1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝜏1subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛𝔼superscriptnorm∇𝑓superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑚𝑡𝑖2\displaystyle-\eta(\frac{1}{2n}-\frac{L\eta}{2n}-\frac{L^{2}\eta^{2}\tau(\tau-1)}{n})\sum_{t=0}^{\tau-1}\sum_{i\in[n]}\mathbb{E}\|\nabla f(\mathbf{w}_{m,t}^{i})\|^{2}
+L​τ​η2​σ22​n+L2​η3​σ2​(n+1)​τ​(τ−1)2​n,𝐿𝜏superscript𝜂2superscript𝜎22𝑛superscript𝐿2superscript𝜂3superscript𝜎2𝑛1𝜏𝜏12𝑛\displaystyle+\frac{L\tau\eta^{2}\sigma^{2}}{2n}+\frac{L^{2}\eta^{3}\sigma^{2}(n+1)\tau(\tau-1)}{2n}, (56)

which concludes Lemma 2.

VI-C Proof of Lemma 3

According to the definitions in (33), 𝐰^m+1subscript^𝐰𝑚1\hat{\mathbf{w}}_{m+1} is the model with the quantization effect on both the uplink and downlink, and 𝐰¯m,τsubscript¯𝐰𝑚𝜏\bar{\mathbf{w}}_{m,\tau} is the model without quantization. Here, we calculate the quantization error bound. Using Assumption 1, we have

𝔼∥\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\| 𝐰^m+1−𝐰¯m,τ∥2=𝔼∥𝐰m+1n∑i∈[n]Q1(𝐰m,τi−Q2(𝐰m))−1n∑i∈[n]𝐰m,τi∥2\displaystyle\hat{\mathbf{w}}_{m+1}-\bar{\mathbf{w}}_{m,\tau}\|^{2}=\mathbb{E}\|\mathbf{w}_{m}+\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i\in[n]}Q_{1}(\mathbf{w}_{m,\tau}^{i}-Q_{2}(\mathbf{w}_{m}))-\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i\in[n]}\mathbf{w}_{m,\tau}^{i}\|^{2}
=𝔼​‖𝐰m−Q2​(𝐰m)+Q2​(𝐰m)+1n​∑i∈[n]Q1​(𝐰m,τi−Q2​(𝐰m))−1n​∑i∈[n]𝐰m,τi‖2absent𝔼superscriptnormsubscript𝐰𝑚subscript𝑄2subscript𝐰𝑚subscript𝑄2subscript𝐰𝑚1𝑛subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛subscript𝑄1superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑚𝜏𝑖subscript𝑄2subscript𝐰𝑚1𝑛subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑚𝜏𝑖2\displaystyle=\mathbb{E}\|\mathbf{w}_{m}-Q_{2}(\mathbf{w}_{m})+Q_{2}(\mathbf{w}_{m})+\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i\in[n]}Q_{1}(\mathbf{w}_{m,\tau}^{i}-Q_{2}(\mathbf{w}_{m}))-\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i\in[n]}\mathbf{w}_{m,\tau}^{i}\|^{2}
=𝔼​‖𝐰m−Q2​(𝐰m)+1n​∑i∈[n]Q1​(𝐰m,τi−Q2​(𝐰m))−1n​∑i∈[n](𝐰m,τi−Q2​(𝐰m))‖2absent𝔼superscriptnormsubscript𝐰𝑚subscript𝑄2subscript𝐰𝑚1𝑛subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛subscript𝑄1subscriptsuperscript𝐰𝑖𝑚𝜏subscript𝑄2subscript𝐰𝑚1𝑛subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑚𝜏𝑖subscript𝑄2subscript𝐰𝑚2\displaystyle=\mathbb{E}\|\mathbf{w}_{m}-Q_{2}(\mathbf{w}_{m})+\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i\in[n]}Q_{1}(\mathbf{w}^{i}_{m,\tau}-Q_{2}(\mathbf{w}_{m}))-\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i\in[n]}(\mathbf{w}_{m,\tau}^{i}-Q_{2}(\mathbf{w}_{m}))\|^{2}
≤𝔼​‖𝐰m−Q2​(𝐰m)‖2+𝔼​‖1n​∑i∈[n]Q1​(𝐰m,τi−Q2​(𝐰m))−1n​∑i∈[n](𝐰m,τi−Q2​(𝐰m))‖2absent𝔼superscriptnormsubscript𝐰𝑚subscript𝑄2subscript𝐰𝑚2𝔼superscriptnorm1𝑛subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛subscript𝑄1subscriptsuperscript𝐰𝑖𝑚𝜏subscript𝑄2subscript𝐰𝑚1𝑛subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑚𝜏𝑖subscript𝑄2subscript𝐰𝑚2\displaystyle\leq\mathbb{E}\|\mathbf{w}_{m}-Q_{2}(\mathbf{w}_{m})\|^{2}+\mathbb{E}\|\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i\in[n]}Q_{1}(\mathbf{w}^{i}_{m,\tau}-Q_{2}(\mathbf{w}_{m}))-\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i\in[n]}(\mathbf{w}_{m,\tau}^{i}-Q_{2}(\mathbf{w}_{m}))\|^{2}
≤𝔼​‖𝐰m−Q2​(𝐰m)‖2+1n2​∑i∈[n]𝔼​‖Q1​(𝐰m,τi−Q2​(𝐰m))−(𝐰m,τi−Q2​(𝐰m))‖2absent𝔼superscriptnormsubscript𝐰𝑚subscript𝑄2subscript𝐰𝑚21superscript𝑛2subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛𝔼superscriptnormsubscript𝑄1subscriptsuperscript𝐰𝑖𝑚𝜏subscript𝑄2subscript𝐰𝑚superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑚𝜏𝑖subscript𝑄2subscript𝐰𝑚2\displaystyle\leq\mathbb{E}\|\mathbf{w}_{m}-Q_{2}(\mathbf{w}_{m})\|^{2}+\frac{1}{n^{2}}\sum_{i\in[n]}\mathbb{E}\|Q_{1}(\mathbf{w}^{i}_{m,\tau}-Q_{2}(\mathbf{w}_{m}))-(\mathbf{w}_{m,\tau}^{i}-Q_{2}(\mathbf{w}_{m}))\|^{2}
≤d​(R​(𝐰m)sm)2+1n2​∑i∈[n]d​(R​(Δ​𝐰mi)smi)2,absent𝑑superscript𝑅subscript𝐰𝑚subscript𝑠𝑚21superscript𝑛2subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛𝑑superscript𝑅Δsuperscriptsubscript𝐰𝑚𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑠𝑚𝑖2\displaystyle\leq d(\frac{R(\mathbf{w}_{m})}{s_{m}})^{2}+\frac{1}{n^{2}}\sum_{i\in[n]}d(\frac{R(\Delta\mathbf{w}_{m}^{i})}{s_{m}^{i}})^{2}, (57)

which concludes Lemma 3.
